summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for health care providers outlining infection prevention and control measures to be taken in response to COVID-19
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care, Public Health Wales, Public Health Agency, Northern Ireland, Health Protection Scotland, Public Health England
when_introduced_duration:
Published 10 January 2020. Updates up to 1 April include: 

31 January 2020 - Updated waste categorisation and terminology for novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV).

14 February 2020 - Revised guidance.

6 March 2020 - Changes to PPE and mask and respiratory recommendations for different situations; incorporated existing advice on safe use of point-of-care tests including blood gas machines and updated advice on IPC in operating theatres.

13 March 2020 - Added 'Infection prevention and control guidance for pandemic coronavirus'.

21 March 2020 - Added new guidance on when to use a face mask or FFP3 respirator.

21 March 2020 - Added new guidance for putting on and taking off personal protective equipment for non-aerosol generating procedures.

27 March 2020 - Revised sections on aerosol generating procedures and theatres.

23 March 2020 - Moved guidance for personal protective equipment (PPE) for aerosol generating procedures and for non-aerosol generating procedures to new, separate pages.

Later major updates are logged separately
why_stated_aims: This document provides guidance and information on infection prevention and control procedures to inform and advise local healthcare planning for COVID-19.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Outlines range of infection prevention and control measures

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for clinicians on the investigation and initial clinical management of possible cases of COVID-19 infection
introduced_by: Public Health England
when_introduced_duration: Published 10 January 2020. Later updated e.g. case definitions and flow charts
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Information provided on case definitions, and the initial assessment and investigation of possible cases of COVID-19 infection.

summary_of_measure_change: Public Health England offers advice for travellers to Wuhan
introduced_by: Public Health England
targeted_at: General public travelling to Hubei Province
when_introduced_duration: Published 10 January. Later major updates to travel advice logged separately
why_stated_aims: In order to minimise the risk of transmission
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Travellers are advised to take simple precautions such as practicing good hand and personal hygiene and minimise contact with birds and animals in markets in Wuhan as a further precaution.

summary_of_measure_change: An interim recommendation is made to classify COVID-19 as a high consequence infectious disease (HCID) in the UK
introduced_by: Public Health England
when_introduced_duration: Added as a high consequence infectious disease on 16 January 2020. Later changes logged separately.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: NA

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for primary care professionals outlining actions to be taken around dealing with potential COVID-19 patients in primary care settings, when transferring them to other settings, and environmental cleaning [now withdrawn]
introduced_by: Public Health England
when_introduced_duration:
Published 21 January 2020. Now withdrawn. 

Updates to guidance before withdrawal include:
18 March 2020 - Updated to reflect stay at home guidance.

25 February 2020 - Updated specified countries and areas.

20 February 2020 - Updated 'Actions to take' regarding use of surgical face masks.

6 February 2020 - Change to relevant travel history: now China, Hong Kong, Japan, Macau, Malaysia, Republic of Korea, Singapore, Taiwan, or Thailand.

30 January 2020 - Replaced Wuhan with "mainland China, not including Hong Kong and Macao".

27 January 2020 - Added advice on cleaning of primary care premises following a possible case.
why_stated_aims: Primary care professionals can use this information to reduce the risk of spread of infection during and following consultation with a suspected case of COVID-19.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Guidance covers: (a) actions to take, including dealing with potential cases of COVID-19 when taking bookings, identifying potential cases at reception; wearing PPE during face to face assessments (b) patient transfers (c) environmental cleaning following a possible case.

summary_of_measure_change: Department of Health and Social Care and Public Health England release statement on enhanced monitoring of passengers travelling from Wuhan
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care, Public Health England
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Enhanced monitoring put in place from flights from Wuhan to UK. Passengers will be checked for symptoms and given advice. The risk to the UK population from COVID-19 is assessed as 'low' (raised from 'very low'). 'The UK is well prepared for new diseases and our approach is kept under constant review.'

summary_of_measure_change: Foreign and Commonwealth Office travel advice is updated to recommend against all but essential travel to mainland China
introduced_by: Foreign and Commonwealth Office
targeted_at: General public travelling to and from China
when_introduced_duration: Updated advice published 28 January. Later major updates to travel advice logged separately
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: NA

summary_of_measure_change: UK Chief Medical Officers raise risk of COVID-19 to the public from low to moderate, permitting the government to escalate planning
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
why_stated_aims: To escalate planning and preparation in case of a more widespread outbreak
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Chief Medical Officers' advise an increase of the UK risk level from low to moderate: 'This does not mean we think the risk to individuals in the UK has changed at this stage, but that government should plan for all eventualities.'

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for professionals on advising the general public [now withdrawn]
introduced_by: Public Health England
targeted_at: Professionals in advising the general public
when_introduced_duration: Published 25 February 2020. Withdrawn 13 March 2020 and superseded by stay at home guidance
why_stated_aims: Not stated - broad aims to reduce spread
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Includes guidance on: (a) general principles to prevent spread (handwashing, cleaning, stay home if unwell (b) Actions on return from China and specified countries and areas (c) Action on presentation of symptoms (d) feeling unwell when away from home

summary_of_measure_change: COVID-19 public information campaign launched
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
why_stated_aims: To advise the public on how to slow the spread of COVID-19 and reduce the impact on NHS services
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: UK government and NHS-branded information will appear in radio, print, media and social media

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for healthcare providers on dealing with healthcare workers who have been put at risk of contracting COVID-19 [now withdrawn]
introduced_by: Public Health England
when_introduced_duration: Published 3 February 2020. Later updated and eventually withdrawn on 13 March 2020 and superseded by stay at home guidance
why_stated_aims: Reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Health care providers should use their communication systems to message all staff in their organisation, stating that if a health care worker has travelled to or transited through a specified country or area and has returned to the UK in the past 14 days, the health care worker should: notify their line manager and occupational health manager immediately if they have already returned to work; if not already at work, notify their line manager and occupational health manager before returning to work

summary_of_measure_change: Foreign and Commonwealth Office travel advice is updated to recommend that British nationals leave China
introduced_by: Foreign and Commonwealth Office
when_introduced_duration: Updated advice published 4 February 2020. Later major updates to travel advice logged separately
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: NA

summary_of_measure_change: Foreign and Commonwealth Office travel advice is updated for people returning from Hubei Province and new advice issued for people returning from China, Thailand, Japan, Republic of Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia or Macau
introduced_by: Foreign and Commonwealth Office
targeted_at: General public returning from  Hubei Province and selected countries
when_introduced_duration: Updated advice published 7 February 2020. Later major updates to travel advice logged separately
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Those who have travelled from Wuhan or Hubei Province in the last 14 days should immediately, even if you do not have symptoms of the virus: stay indoors and avoid contact with other people as you would with the flu; call NHS 111 to inform them of your recent travel to the area. Those who have returned to the UK from China, Thailand, Japan, Republic of Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia or Macau in the last 14 days and develop symptoms of cough or fever or shortness of breath, should immediately: stay indoors and avoid contact with other people as you would with the flu; call NHS 111 to inform them of your recent travel to the country.
notes: Updated from PHE travel guidance issued 10 January.

summary_of_measure_change: COVID-19 diagnostic testing is rolled out to 12 labs across the UK
introduced_by: Public Health England
when_introduced_duration: Announced 7 February 2020. Starting on Monday 10 February 2020
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Diagnostic test is rolled from PHE's laboratory in London to 12 laboratories across the UK. The increase in diagnostic capacity increases testing capacity to more than 1,000 people a day for England.

summary_of_measure_change: Government introduces legal powers to impose restrictions on individuals at risk of spreading COVID-19 [now revoked]
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
targeted_at: Patients and general public believed to have COVID-19 and people who have arrived in England on a ship, aircraft or train and have left an infected area in the previous 14 days
when_introduced_duration: Introduced 10 February 2020. Regulations revoked and superseded by Coronavirus Act 2020
why_stated_aims: HoC intro: 'containment [...] ensuring that people who are contacts of known cases, or who are considered to be at high risk of ​infection, are isolated from others for a period of time, ensuring that they cannot infect others but can readily access help if they fall ill". Explanatory Notes: “to level up across the UK, so that the actions to tackle this threat can be carried out effectively across all four nations'
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Health Protection (Coronavirus) Regulations 2020: detention of patients with COVID-19 regulations, giving health professionals the power to detain patients with COVID-19 for the specific purposes of screening and assessment, or to isolate them for a period of time, and allowing police constables to detain people suspected of having the virus. Restrictive measures for screening, isolation and contact – no provision for compulsory treatment of a person

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for education providers on how to address COVID-19 in educational settings
introduced_by: Public Health England
when_introduced_duration: Published 17 February 2020. Later updated e.g. on 7 April 2020 to reflect the announcement on school closures and on 12 May 2020 to prepare for reopening
why_stated_aims: This guidance will assist staff in addressing COVID-19 in educational settings
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Guidance covers: (a) What to do if someone develops symptoms of COVID-19 on site (b) Limiting spread of COVID-19 in educational settings (c) Cleaning and Waste (d) Tools and resources for sharing public health information

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for social, community care and residential care providers to address COVID-19 in their care settings [now withdrawn]
introduced_by: Public Health England
targeted_at: Social, community and residential care employers to inform their staff
when_introduced_duration: Published 25 February. Withdrawn 13 March 2020 and superseded by residential care, supported living and home care guidance
why_stated_aims: This guidance will assist social, community and residential care employers in providing advice to their staff. This guidance is intended for the current position in the UK where there is currently no transmission of COVID-19 in the community.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Guidance covers: (a) principles to prevent the spread of infection, including handwashing/ face touching, staying home if unwell; (b) Face masks, including guidance that only recommended to be worn by infected individuals when advised by a healthcare worker; (c) What to do if an employee becomes unwell and believe they have been exposed to COVID-19; (d) Returning from travel overseas to affected areas, including those returning from Wuhan; (e) What to do if someone with confirmed COVID-19 has recently been in the office, workplace or residential setting, including that closure is not recommended.
notes: Superseded by guidance: COVID-19: residential care, supported living and home care guidance

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published to address COVID-19 in the workplace
introduced_by: Public Health England and Department for Business, Energy & Industrial strategy
targeted_at: Employees, employers and businesses in providing advice about the novel coronavirus (COVID-19).
when_introduced_duration: Published 25 February. Later updated regularly e.g. on 10 March 2020 with new travel advice and 6 April 2020 with guidance on using face masks in public
why_stated_aims: This guidance will assist employers, businesses and their staff in addressing COVID-19. Frequently updated e.g. 6 April 2020 - added guidance on use of face masks in the community
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Guidance covers: social distancing principles, shift and staggering work patterns, stay at home guidance, sick pay and time off work to look after someone, food safety, cleaning and waste disposal, and other areas.

summary_of_measure_change: Public Health England and the NHS establish a new surveillance system to detect cases of COVID-19
introduced_by: Public Health England and NHS
targeted_at: Patients with severe respiratory infections who do not meet the current case definition for COVID-19
why_stated_aims: This new surveillance strategy was established to strengthen existing systems and to prepare for and prevent wider transmission of the virus. It will enable PHE to identify early evidence of spread within England, if this occurs.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Some NHS hospitals have been asked to implement new surveillance at their intensive care units and Severe Respiratory Failure Centres. Samples will be tested from patients with severe respiratory infections who do not meet the current case definition for COVID-19. A programme of testing with a network of around 100 primary care sites across England will also complement the detection system in hospitals, so that both mild and more unwell cases can be found.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published on the cleaning of non-healthcare settings
introduced_by: Public Health England
targeted_at: Any non-healthcare setting e.g. workplaces, offices, waiting rooms, hotel rooms, student accommodation, boarding schools
why_stated_aims: COVID-19 can spread through contact with a surface or object that has the virus on it. Cleaning minimises the spread of COVID-19. Normal cleaning methods do kill this virus. Cleaners, caretakers and concierges play an important role in keeping people in their buildings protected, particularly the most vulnerable.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Guidance on 26 February for cleaning includes: (a) cleaning an area with normal household disinfectant after someone with suspected COVID-19 has left will reduce the risk of passing on the infection (b) wearing disposable  gloves and aprons and dispose of after cleaning (c) using a disposable cloth, first clean hard surfaces with warm soapy water. Then disinfect these surfaces with the cleaning products you normally use. Pay particular attention to frequently touched areas and surfaces (d) if an area has been heavily contaminated from a person with coronavirus, consider using protection for the eyes, mouth and nose, as well as wearing gloves and an apron (e) wash hands regularly with soap and water for 20 seconds, and after removing gloves, aprons and other protection used while cleaning.

summary_of_measure_change: NHS rolls out services on NHS sites to test people for COVID-19, including offering ‘drive through’ testing
introduced_by: NHS England and Improvement
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: The new service, provided by Central London Community Healthcare NHS Trust, is only accessed through a referral from NHS 111. After being referred through NHS 111, people are invited to an appointment in their car, during which two community nurses carry out a swab in the nose and mouth, which are checked and assessed within 72 hours. People are asked to self-isolate while checks are completed, to prevent any potential onward transmission of the virus.

summary_of_measure_change: Expanded public information campaign is announced focusing on handwashing for 20 seconds
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
why_stated_aims: Making sure the public knows exactly what they should be doing to keep themselves and others safe' - Matt Hancock
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Campaign in print media, radio, online and in public places, including billboards

summary_of_measure_change: COVID-19 is listed as a notifiable disease in law
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: On 5 March 2020, a statutory instrument was made into law that adds COVID-19 to the list of notifiable diseases and SARS-COV-2 to the list of notifiable causative agents. This change was made by adding them to the Health Protection (Notification) Regulations 2010. This change in law requires all clinicians to report all cases of COVID-19 to Public Health England.

summary_of_measure_change: Government launches a new taskforce to provide support and advice to Local Resilience Forums
introduced_by: Ministry of Housing, Communities & Local Government and The Rt Hon Robert Jenrick MP
why_stated_aims: To help 'them fully prepare for a range of scenarios at a local level'
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: The taskforce will bring together senior experts from across key sectors – including resilience, local government, public health and adult social care fields – who will assess Local Resilience Forum (LRF) plans and provide support and advice to ensure they are robust.

summary_of_measure_change: Updated guidance published for travellers returning from specified countries and areas [now withdrawn]
introduced_by: Public Health England
when_introduced_duration: Updated 10 March 2020. Withdrawn 13 March 2020 and superseded by stay at home guidance
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Travellers returning from Category 1 areas should self-isolate, even if asymptomatic, and use the 111 online COVID-19 service to find out what to do next. Go home or to your destination and then self-isolate. Travellers returning from Category 2 areas do not need to undertake any special measures, but if they develop symptoms they should self-isolate and call NHS 111.

summary_of_measure_change: £10m of new funding is announced to increase the capacity and capability of diagnostic testing and surveillance
introduced_by: MH Treasury Budget 2020
when_introduced_duration: Budget published 11 March 2020. Timetable for funding not stated
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: By providing an additional £10m of new funding to the Department of Health and Social Care. Testing to be facilitated through Public Health England

summary_of_measure_change: People aged 70+ and those with pre-existing health conditions are advised against cruise ship travel
introduced_by: Foreign & Commonwealth Office
why_stated_aims: It follows a number of cruise ships around the world being locked down due to COVID-19 outbreaks on board.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: The Foreign & Commonwealth Office advises British nationals aged 70 and over and those with pre-existing health conditions against cruise ship travel at this time.

summary_of_measure_change: Government move from the 'contain' to the 'delay' phase of its response to COVID-19. People with symptoms are told to stay at home for 7 days and that they do not need to be tested
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
targeted_at: (a) People with symptoms that may be caused by COVID-19 (b) those living in households with someone who shows symptoms that may be caused by COVID-19
when_introduced_duration: Published 12 March 2020. Later major updates logged separately
why_stated_aims: Measures will greatly reduce the overall amount of infection the household could pass on to others in the community
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: People with symptoms told to stay at home for 7 days from when the symptoms appeared. After 7 days, if a person still has a high temperature they should keep self-isolating until the temperature returns to normal. They do not need to continue isolating if they just have a cough after 7 days. Those with symptoms are told:  'do not go to a GP surgery, pharmacy or hospital; you do not need to contact 111 to tell them you’re staying at home; testing for coronavirus (COVID-19) is not needed if you’re staying at home'

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for reducing risk of transmission of COVID-19 in residential care provision [now withdrawn and not available]
introduced_by: Public Health England
targeted_at: Local authorities, Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs),  and registered providers of accommodation for people who need personal or nursing care.
when_introduced_duration: Published 13 March 2020. Withdrawn on 6 April 2020 and replaced by guidance on admission and care of people in care homes
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Not available

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for supported living provision to support planning and preparation in the event of an outbreak or widespread transmission of COVID-19
introduced_by: Public Health England
targeted_at: local authorities, CCGs,  community health services and providers of care and support delivered to people in their own homes, including for people with mental health conditions, learning disabilities or autistic adults.
when_introduced_duration: Published 13 March 2020. Later updated e.g. on 19 March 2020 added information on implications of household isolation guidance
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Guidance includes steps that supported living providers can take to maintain service delivery, if a supported living care worker is concerned they may have COVID-19, if someone in supported living has symptoms of COVID-19, applying ‘household isolation’ principles. Includes detail of government and local authority support.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for home care provision to support planning and preparation in the event of an outbreak or widespread transmission of COVID-19
introduced_by: Public Health England
targeted_at: local authorities, CCGs and registered providers, who support and deliver care to people in their own homes, including community health services.
when_introduced_duration: Published 13 March 2020. Later updated e.g. on 19 March 2020 added information on implications of household isolation guidance
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Guidance includes steps for home care providers to maintain delivery of care, if the individual being cared for has symptoms of COVID-19, if an individual being cared for does not have symptoms but is part of a household that is isolating, if neither the individual nor the care worker have symptoms of COVID-19. Includes steps for local authorities to support home care provision.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for reducing risk of transmission of COVID-19 in prisons and other places of detention
introduced_by: Ministry of Justice and Her Majesty’s Prison and Probation Service
targeted_at: Prisons and other prescribed places of detention
when_introduced_duration: Published 16 March 2020. Later updated e.g. on 24 March 2020 an update was added to say prison visits are temporarily cancelled
why_stated_aims: This is vital for keeping prisoners and staff safe and preventing the spread of the virus.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Prison visits are temporarily suspended. The usual regime in prisons has been paused temporarily to apply social distancing. This means prisoners can no longer take part in usual recreational activities such as using the gym, going to worship or visiting the library. Only essential workers such as kitchen staff or wing cleaners will continue with their jobs but people will still get paid. All face-to-face Parole Board hearings and new jury trials have been temporarily suspended. The Parole Board will progress cases through a combination of remote hearings and a paper review process, sometimes combined with case management hearings.

summary_of_measure_change: Government announces new social distancing measures, including for anyone in a household with symptoms of COVID-19 to stay home for 14 days
introduced_by: Secretary of State for Health and Social Care
targeted_at: Directed at everyone, but especially important for those older than 70, for pregnant women and for those with some health conditions. And especially true of London.
why_stated_aims: To protect the NHS by building it up and flattening the curve. And to protect life by safeguarding those who are most vulnerable.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: New measures: (a) Those with symptoms or people in household with symptoms – stay home for 14 days (except exercise and those who can't receive deliveries at home). (b) Everyone else - advise against all unnecessary social contact with others and all unnecessary travel. Including working from home if possible, avoiding pubs, clubs, cinemas and restaurants. (c) Government withdrawing support for mass gatherings. (d) Increasing testing 'radically further' - 'we have already increased the number of tests to 5,000 a day and this is now on its way to 10,000 and then radically further.' (e) We are ramping up our communications effort so that people know what steps they need to take to protect themselves, others and the NHS.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published on new social distancing measures and vulnerable people advised to be particularly stringent in following measures [now withdrawn]
introduced_by: Public Health England
targeted_at: Everyone in the UK, including children, older people and vulnerable people.
when_introduced_duration: Published 16 March 2020. Later major updates logged separately e.g. 23 March 2020 stay at home and away from others guidance. Guidance was withdrawn on 11 May 2020 and superseded by the following guidance: Staying alert and safe (social distancing)
why_stated_aims: To reduce social interaction between people. This will help reduce the transmission of COVID-19
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
Those not in vulnerable groups are advised against social mixing in the community,  to use remote access to essential services, less public transport and work from home where possible. 

Those in vulnerable groups, 70+ or pregnant are strongly advised against social mixing in the community, to use remote access to essential services, less public transport, and work from home where possible.

summary_of_measure_change: Government advises that that mass gatherings should not take place, in line with new social distancing measures
introduced_by: Department of Digital, Culture, Media and Sport; Public Health England; Department of Health and Social Care
targeted_at: Those arranging or planning to attend events in the UK
why_stated_aims: Social distancing measures to help reduce the transmission of coronavirus
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: In line with the social distancing guidance it is advised that large gatherings should not take place. While the risks of transmitting the disease at mass gatherings are relatively low, these steps will also allow emergency services that would have been deployed for these events to be prioritised in alleviating pressure on public services.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for shipping and sea ports
introduced_by: Department for Transport, Public Health England, Maritime and Coastguard Agency
when_introduced_duration: Guidance published 16 March 2020. Guidance later updated
why_stated_aims: Guidance will assist ships and sea ports in providing advice to staff on addressing COVID-19.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Guidance on measures to stop the spread of the virus, covering (a) what to do if you have had a person with confirmed coronavirus (COVID-19) in a marine setting (b) specific action for ships and shipping companies (c) limiting spread of coronavirus (COVID-19) in marine settings (d) disembarkation

summary_of_measure_change: Next stage of public information campaign announced focusing on new guidance for households with possible COVID-19 infection
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care and Public Health England
why_stated_aims: Government has taken the further measure of asking whole households to isolate because it is likely that people living with others will infect each other or be infected already. Staying at home for 14 days will greatly reduce the overall amount of infection the household could pass on to others in the community.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: The new guidance will set out that individuals will still be asked to self-isolate for 7 days from the onset of COVID-19 symptoms but any individuals in the household will now be asked to self-isolate for 14 days from that moment as well. The new phase of the campaign will build on the existing TV, radio, online, digital and billboard adverts currently visible all over the country. These reinforce the importance of washing your hands more often and for 20 seconds, and ask people to self-isolate for 7 days if they develop a high temperature or a new continuous cough, however mild.

summary_of_measure_change: Government commits to increasing testing for COVID-19 to 25,000 hospital patients a day and calls on industry to develop an antibody test
introduced_by: Prime Minister and Secretary of State for Health and Social Care
when_introduced_duration: Announced 17 March 2020. Increased capacity expected to be ready within four weeks
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Prime Minister and Health Secretary promised industry leaders that they would be given whatever support they need to help government increase testing capabilities across the country. The Prime Minister also called on companies to work with the government to rapidly develop a test to establish whether people have developed immunity.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for Councils covering a range of measures to address COVID-19
introduced_by: Ministry of Housing, Communities & Local Government
when_introduced_duration: Published 17 March 2020. Has frequently been updated to reflect wider policy changes and links to other guidance
why_stated_aims: Package of guidance on range of measures to tackle the outbreak of COVID-19.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Wide-ranging guidance including on housing, homelessness, the closure of certain businesses due to social distancing measures, granting restaurant to operate takeaways and shielding most vulnerable (logged separately) and guidance for schools and education settings (logged separately)

summary_of_measure_change: Foreign and Commonwealth Office travel advice is updated to advise against all non-essential world-wide travel
introduced_by: Foreign & Commonwealth Office
why_stated_aims: Travel advice reflects the pace at which other countries are either closing their borders or implementing restrictive measures
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Government advise against all non-essential world-wide travel

summary_of_measure_change: COVID-19 is no longer considered to be a high consequence infectious disease (HCID) in the UK
introduced_by: Public Health England
why_stated_aims: Now that more is known about COVID-19, the public health bodies in the UK have reviewed the most up to date information about COVID-19 against the UK HCID criteria. They have determined that several features have now changed; in particular, more information is available about mortality rates (low overall), and there is now greater clinical awareness and a specific and sensitive laboratory test, the availability of which continues to increase.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Cases of COVID-19 are no longer managed by HCID treatment centres only. All healthcare workers managing possible and confirmed cases should follow the updated national infection and prevention (IPC) guidance for COVID-19, which supersedes all previous IPC guidance for COVID-19.

summary_of_measure_change: Government announces further social distancing measures to close entertainment, hospitality and indoor leisure premises
introduced_by: Ministry of Housing, Communities & Local Government and The Rt Hon Robert Jenrick MP
targeted_at: Entertainment, hospitality and indoor leisure premises across the UK
when_introduced_duration: Measures introduced from end of trading Friday 20 March 2020
why_stated_aims: To delay the spread of COVID-19
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Some businesses and venues including all pubs, bars and restaurants are instructed  to close from end of trading Friday 20 March 2020

summary_of_measure_change: Schools, colleges and nurseries in England ordered to close ‘until further notice’
introduced_by: Prime Minister and Secretary of State for Education
targeted_at: Schools, colleges and nurseries in England
when_introduced_duration: Announced 18 March, ordered to close from 20 March to last 'until further notice'
why_stated_aims: To slow the spread of the virus
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Schools, colleges and nurseries in England close for the vast majority of children. Schools are to continue to make provisions for the children of key workers who would otherwise be forced to stay home and the most vulnerable children.

summary_of_measure_change: Government publish the scientific evidence provided to SAGE supporting the UK government response
introduced_by: Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (SAGE)
when_introduced_duration: Published 20 March 2020. New papers and meeting minutes frequently added.
why_stated_aims: In fast moving situations, transparency should be at the heart of what the government does. We have therefore published the statements and the accompanying evidence to demonstrate how our understanding of COVID-19 has continued to evolve as new data emerges, and how SAGE’s advice has quickly adapted to new findings that reflect a changing situation.'
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: The Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (SAGE) provides ministers and officials with evidence-based scientific advice in emergencies. This release contains the methods and findings that have informed SAGE advice on the COVID-19 outbreak to date. SAGE will publish: all past minutes and supporting documents. Papers will be published chronologically and thematically in the coming weeks; future minutes and supporting documentation will be published within 1 month of the meeting having taken place, and earlier where possible.

summary_of_measure_change: Government announces shielding measures - up to 1.5 million people identified as being at higher risk of severe illness if they contract COVID-19 should stay at home
introduced_by: Ministry of Housing, Communities & Local Government, Department of Health and Social Care, Public Health England, The Rt Hon Matt Hancock MP, and The Rt Hon Robert Jenrick MP
targeted_at: People identified as highest risk of being hospitalised by COVID-19
when_introduced_duration: Announced 21 March 2020. This group should not leave their house for at least 12 weeks starting on 22 March 2020
why_stated_aims: This will be an especially worrying time for those with serious underlying health conditions and that is why we are urgently acting to ensure extremely vulnerable individuals are taking extra steps to shield themselves, and that the essential items they need are supplied to them.'
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
Up to 1.5 million people in England identified by the NHS as being at higher risk of severe illness if they contract COVID-19 should stay at home to protect themselves. The people identified as the most vulnerable in their communities will be contacted directly – including in person where necessary – as a priority. A raft of new measures, including a helpline for the most in need of support, have been set out for those considered to be extremely vulnerable due to their medical conditions, so people know exactly how to care for themselves and others in the coming months. A new Local Support System will make sure those individuals self-isolating at home and who are without a support network of friends and family will receive basic groceries. Community pharmacies will support those who need help getting their medicines delivered.  

The government is working with a partnership of the groceries industry, local government, local resilience and emergency partners, and voluntary groups, to ensure that essential items can start to be delivered as soon as possible. The armed forces, already in local communities helping Local Resilience Forums and local councils on their COVID-19 response plans, will support this effort and are at the heart of local planning in response to this crisis.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published on shielding and protecting people defined on medical grounds as extremely vulnerable
introduced_by: Public Health England
targeted_at: People, including children, who are at very high risk of severe illness from coronavirus because of an underlying health condition, and for their family, friends and carers. In situations where the extremely vulnerable person is living in their own home, with or without additional support. This includes the extremely clinically vulnerable people living in long-term care facilities, either for the elderly or persons with special needs.
when_introduced_duration: Announced 22 March 2020. Guidance published 21 March 2020. Guidance later updated
why_stated_aims: Shielding is a measure to protect people who are clinically extremely vulnerable by minimising all interaction between those who are extremely vulnerable and others.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Targeted group advised to (a) stay at home at all times and avoid any face-to-face contact for a period of at least 12 weeks from the day you receive your letter. (b) continue visits from people who provide essential support, but carers and care workers must stay away if they have any of the symptoms. (c) All people coming to your home should wash their hands on arrival to your house and often while they are there. (d) you should have an alternative list of people who can help you with your care if your main carer becomes unwell. (e) If you think you have developed symptoms of COVID-19  seek clinical advice using the NHS 111 online coronavirus service or call NHS 111 as soon as you get symptoms.

summary_of_measure_change: Professor Sharon Peacock tells science and technology select committee that antibody testing will be available to general public 'in the near future'
introduced_by: na
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
Professor Peacock: Yes. I think 3.5 million have been ordered – that is the amount we have – and further millions are being ordered today. But we need to make sure that we understand how they operate, because they are brand-new tests; they have not been used by us before. They will be tested in Oxford, and once we are assured that they work they will be rolled out to the community. We are rolling out a programme alongside that to check that they work in the field, in people’s homes. PHE has a study and will recruit people to have a second blood test, to get checked with a gold standard test to make sure that they are truly working as we expect.

Q130       Chair: Can you give us a feeling of when you might expect the testing of the tests to be completed so that they can begin to be sent out by Amazon?

Professor Peacock: Testing the test is a small matter, and I anticipate that it would be done by the end of this week.

Q131       Chair: By the beginning of next week, should members of the public be able to order their home tests and test themselves?

Professor Peacock: I would be somewhat less categorical about the date, but, in the near future, people will be able to order a test whereby they can test themselves or go to Boots, or somewhere similar, to have their finger-prick test done.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance on infection prevention and control measures for health care providers is updated to reflect new definition of contact and new requirements for handwashing and reuse of PPE

when_introduced_duration: Updated  2 April 2020. Major later updates logged separately
why_stated_aims:
PHE has worked with NHSEI and the Devolved Administrations to review the UK’s infection prevention and control recommendations for COVID-19. PHE also consulted with the Royal College of Nursing, other Royal Colleges and professional societies.

Having assessed the available evidence and feedback received from guidance users, we have updated sections to improve the guidance and ensure that we continue to make recommendations that will help prevent the spread of COVID-19 and keep people safe.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Main changes to the guidance include: (a) new tables to explain PPE use in different clinical scenarios (b) the guidance explains that in some circumstances PPE can be worn for an entire session (such as a ward round) and does not need to be changed between each patient (c) patient contact is now defined as being within 2 metres (rather than within 1 metre) of a patient (d) hand-washing advice has been updated to include washing of forearms, when forearms have been exposed or may have been exposed (e) FFP2 and N95 respirators may be used for some aerosol-generating procedures if FFP3 respirators are not available (f) advice on re-usable PPE components, including the need to refer to manufacturer’s guidance on decontamination (g) recommendations about the use of facemasks by patients.

summary_of_measure_change: Government announces a major new programme of home testing (antigen and antibody) for COVID-19 to track the progress of the infection across England
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
why_stated_aims: Accurate testing for the virus on a wide scale will provide authorities with a clearer picture of the current spread of the disease and the number of people who have previously caught it. It will help identify individuals who may have some immunity to the virus, and to plan services for those who do not.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
The programme, commissioned by the Department of Health and Social Care, is being led by a team of scientists, clinicians and researchers at Imperial College London alongside colleagues at Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust, and supported by Ipsos MORI. 

In the first part of the Real-time Assessment of Community Transmission (REACT-1) programme, 100,000 randomly selected people across England will be tested for antigens indicating the presence of the virus. 

In the second part of the programme (REACT-2), a number of different antibody tests will be assessed for their accuracy and ease of use at home. The antibody tests will first be carried out on volunteers from Imperial Healthcare NHS Trust who are known to have had the virus to establish their accuracy. Three hundred public volunteers will also be given a sample test to self-administer. If successful, the test will then be distributed to a larger cohort of up to 10,000 people. 

A further stage will involve up to 5,000 key workers, who will both self-test and have the test administered by a health professional. These results will also be compared with the results of blood samples from participants to provide more information about the accuracy of the tests. If antibody self-testing is found to work with a high degree of accuracy, acceptability and usability, it will be rolled out to 100,000 people later this year, to provide an indication of the prevalence of COVID-19 based on the presence of coronavirus antibodies.

summary_of_measure_change: Government publishes 'Our Plan to Rebuild: The UK Government’s COVID-19 recovery strategy'
introduced_by: Cabinet Office
when_introduced_duration: Published 11 May 2020. Step one changes to policy come into effect on Wednesday 13 May in England
why_stated_aims:
[W]hile we hope for a [vaccine] breakthrough, hope is not a plan. A mass vaccine or treatment may be
more than a year away. Indeed, in a worst-case scenario, we may never find a vaccine. So our
plan must countenance a situation where we are in this, together, for the long haul, even while
doing all we can to avoid that outcome.'
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
The strategy describes three phases to recovery and explains that we are leaving phase 1 and entering phase 2. The phases are (1) where the government sought to contain, delay, research and mitigate; (2) 'Smarter controls' - where existing restrictions are replaced with measures that have the largest effect on controlling the pandemic with the lowest health, economic and social cost. These will be announced in steps, with conditions for progressing through each step, and the option to reimpose restrictions; (3) 'Reliable treatment' - where the roll out of an effective treatment and/or vaccine allows us to move to a stage where the effects of the virus are reduced to a manageable level. The strategy describes a three-step 'roadmap to lifting restrictions'. Step one policies that apply from Wednesday 13 May in England include: (a) Work - workers from particular sectors who cannot work from home should travel to work if their workplace is open. Workplaces should follow the new “COVID-19 Secure” guidelines. (b) Schools - schools should urge more children who would benefit from attending in person to do so. Paid childcare can take place subject to being able to meet the public health principles. (c) Travel - everybody (including critical workers) should continue to avoid public transport wherever possible and social distancing guidance on public transport must be followed. (d) Face-coverings - people should aim to wear a face-covering in enclosed spaces. (e) Public spaces - as well as exercising as much as people like, people can now also drive to outdoor spaces and spend time outdoors subject to not meeting up with more than one person from outside their household and compliance with social distancing. Higher fines will be imposed to reflect the increased risk to others of breaking the rules.

The content and timing of the second and third stages of adjustments will depend on the most up-to-date assessment of the risk posed by the virus. 

Fourteen programmes of work support the delivery the plan, including NHS and care capacity and operating model, Protecting care homes, Shielding of the most vulnerable, and Accurate disease monitoring and reactive measures.

why_stated_aims: As the transmission rate in the UK falls, and the number of travellers arriving in the UK begins to increase in the coming months, imported cases may pose a larger threat as they could become a higher proportion of the overall number of infections in the UK and increase the spread of the disease. We need to take action to manage the risk of transmission from this group.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: The measures outlined include: (a) Contact locator form - all arriving passengers required to provide contact and travel information so they can be contacted if they, or someone they may have been in contact with develops the disease. (b) Self isolation - passengers arriving in the UK required to self-isolate for 14 days and could be contacted regularly throughout this period to ensure compliance. (c) Enforcement - failure to comply with the mandatory conditions may face enforcement action. A breach of self-isolation would be punishable with a £1,000 fixed penalty notice in England or potential prosecution and unlimited fine. The level of fine could increase if the risk of infection from abroad increases. The Devolved Administrations will set out their own enforcement approaches. (d) Spot checks - Border Force will undertake checks at the border and may refuse entry to any non-British citizen who refuses to comply with these regulations and isn’t resident in the UK. Failure to complete the form is also punishable by a £100 fixed penalty notice. Public health authorities will conduct random checks in England to ensure compliance with self-isolation requirements. Removal from the country would be considered as a last resort for foreign nationals who refuse to comply with these public health measures.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance sets out how to self-isolate for 14 days if you arrive in the UK on or after 8 June 2020
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
when_introduced_duration: Published 3 June 2020. Came into force 8 June 2020
why_stated_aims:
When you arrive in the UK, it is very important that you stay in your accommodation for 14 days. It can take up to 14 days for you to develop COVID-19 symptoms after you catch the virus and in this time you can unknowingly pass it on to others, even if you don’t have symptoms.

Self-isolating will reduce the chance of a second wave of coronavirus in the UK and help prevent family, friends and the community from contracting COVID-19, as well as helping to protect the NHS.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
Guidance as of 3 June 2020. These rules are for UK residents and all visitors coming into the UK. If you arrive in the UK on or after 8 June 2020, you will not be allowed to leave the place you are staying for the first 14 days in the UK. Before you travel, you should provide your journey, contact details and the address where you will self-isolate. When you arrive in the UK, go straight to the place you are staying. Only use public transport if you have no other option. If you do use public transport, wear a face covering and stay two meters from other people. If necessary, you can stop overnight in safe accommodation before continuing your journey. You should self-isolate in one place for the full 14 days, where you can have necessities delivered, and stay away from others. The people you’re staying with do not need to stay at home, unless they travelled with you. Avoid contact with them and minimise the time you spend in shared spaces. If you do not have any coronavirus symptoms after 14 days, you can stop self-isolating. You will not need to self-isolate for 14 days if you’re travelling to the UK from within the Common Travel Area. A small proportion of people travelling to the UK are exempt (see other guidance for list of exempt people). 

In England, if you do not self-isolate, you can be fined £1,000. If you do not provide an accurate contact detail declaration – or do not update your contact detail form in the limited circumstances where you need to move to another place to self-isolate – you can be fined up to £3,200.

You can have close physical contact with members of support bubble if you and they want to. No limit on how far you can travel to meet members of support bubble. how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
Guidance as of 15 June states: Key principles of how to protect transmission of COVID-19 include: robust social distancing; regular cleaning; good hand and respiratory hygiene. Communication with passengers should reinforce their personal responsibility for safety. Guidance should be used to ensure risk assessments address risks of COVID-19 and incorporates decisions and control measures suitable for the aviation industry. In the following order of priority, risks should be: eliminated; controlled through substituting materials or processes, control through engineering; controlled though identifying and implementing procedures; controlled through using individual protective measures. Passengers must wear a face covering on board aircrafts in England and should wear them in airports. 
Document outlines measures at each stage of passenger journey, including: booking a flight; online check in; travelling to airport; at the airport; security checkpoints; on board; embarkation and disembarkation; on arrival; and leaving the airport.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published on how to travel safely in airports and on aircraft during the COVID-19 outbreak
introduced_by: Department for Transport
when_introduced_duration: Published 11 June 2020. Guidance later updated eg on 15 June to reflect the new requirement for passengers to wear face coverings on aircraft in England.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
Guidance as of 15 June states passengers should: avoid the busiest times and routes; keep two metres apart where possible; minimise time spend near others; wash or sanitise hands regularly. Passengers should not travel: if experiencing COVID-19 symptoms, self-isolating, sharing household within someone with symptoms in last 14 days, or has been advised by the NHS test and trace service to self- isolate.
Passengers must wear a face covering on board an aircraft in England, and should wear one in airports. Before booking a flight, understand the public health requirements of destination country. Where possible, check-in online. Enter the airport on your own, unless flying with members of your household. Avoid touching surfaces in the airport. Each airline will advise you on measures in place for the flight. When entering UK from outside the Common Travel Area - must provide journey and contact details beforehand and self-isolate.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published for local authorities about the 'Local authority test and trace service support grant', including grant allocations, grant conditions, and processes to support local outbreak planning
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
why_stated_aims:
Purpose of grant is to provide support to local authorities towards expenditure lawfully incurred or to be incurred in relation to the mitigation against and management of local outbreaks of COVID-19.
Minister for Patient Safety, Suicide Prevention and Mental Health, Nadine Dorries, said: 'Local authorities play a vital role in the effort to contain COVID-19 in their communities. The funding awarded today will help each local area work hand in hand with Public Health England and contact tracers to focus on the containment of local outbreaks, to control the transmission of this virus.'
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Local authorities across England have been allocated a share of £300m to support the new Test and Trace service. The funding will help local authorities develop tailored outbreak control plans, working with the service, their local NHS and other stakeholders. The Minister of State determines which local authorities the grant is to be paid to and the amount of grant to be paid. Funding has been allocated to councils based on need, with additional funding provided for communities with lower incomes and higher demand for local healthcare settings. The grant shall be payable in one instalment in June 2020. In 2-tier areas, this grant is conditional on upper tier authorities working closely with their lower tier partners. Data on the spread of the virus will be shared with local authorities through the Joint Biosecurity Centre to inform local outbreak planning. A new National Local Government Advisory Board has been established to work with NHS Test and Trace - will share best practice between communities across the country.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance to help places of worship prepare to open for individual prayer on 13 June
introduced_by: Ministry of Housing, Communities & Local Government
when_introduced_duration: Published 12 June 2020. Coming into force 13 June 2020
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Guidance as of 12 June. Under current law places of worship are permitted to open for: funerals; to broadcast acts of worship; to provide essential or urgent services or childcare. From 13 June 2020 they will also be open for individual prayer. Key principles for reopening place of worship: those with COVID-19 symptoms should remain at home and self-isolate; those shielding should continue to follow government advice; if anyone becomes unwell with COVID-19 symptoms, they should be sent home; strict adherence to 2 metres rule; manage queues carefully; extra attention to cleaning; shared washing areas should be closed. Worshippers and staff may wear face coverings to offer protection to others, but not as a replacement for the other ways of managing risk. Strongly advised that individuals: be prevented from touching devotional and other communal objects; avoid touching property belonging to others; avoid activities such as singing or playing instruments; do not have access to food or drink; and be discouraged from cash giving.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance on infection prevention and control updated to reflect new recommendations for hospitals in England coming into force from 15 June, including that all hospital staff should wear a face mask when not in a 'secure zone' and all visitors should wear a face covering

Where this is not possible, all staff should wear a facemask (recommended Type I or Type II, but Type IIR may be used). Visitors and outpatients should wear a face covering for the same reason.

summary_of_measure_change: Government state that passengers who don't follow the new rules on face coverings will not be allowed to travel on public transport
introduced_by: Department for Transport and The Rt Hon Grant Shapps MP
when_introduced_duration: Published 12 June 2020. Coming into force 15 June 2020
why_stated_aims: The Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (SAGE) has set out that using face coverings as a precautionary measure in this setting can provide some additional protection to fellow passengers and can help people to avoid unknowingly spreading the virus if they have it, but are not showing symptoms.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: From 15 June 2020 everyone must wear a face covering when using public transport (face coverings mandatory on buses, coaches, trams, ferries, aircraft and trains). Operators can prevent passengers who refuse to follow the rules from travelling and police can issue fines of £100. Over several days, starting Monday 15 June, face coverings will be handed out free of charge at many locations across the rail network in England. Exemptions for the use of face coverings apply to those with certain health conditions, disabled people and children under the age of 11. Advice remains to avoid public transport where possible.

introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
why_stated_aims: Following rigorous field testing and a trial on the Isle of Wight, we have identified challenges with both our app and the Google/Apple framework [...] Therefore further work to address these challenges is required.'
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
Following a trial on the Isle of Wight, challenges have been identified with the app that aims to support the end-to-end NHS Test and Trace service. The government will be working with Google/Apple ‘to address some of the specific technical challenges identified through our rigorous testing’ of the app’. 
A joint statement from Baroness Dido Harding, Executive Chair of NHS Test and Trace and Matthew Gould, CEO, NHSX says ‘our ambition is to develop an app which will enable anyone with a smartphone to engage with every aspect of the NHS Test and Trace service, from ordering a test through to accessing the right guidance and advice. Health and Social Care Secretary Matt Hancock says ‘as we enter this next phase of research and development we remain determined to continue in our ambition to develop an app which meets the technical, security and user needs of the public and which can complement the NHS Test and Trace service’.

summary_of_measure_change: Government announce plans to ease guidance for over two million shielding people from 6 July 2020
introduced_by: Ministry of Housing, Communities & Local Government and Department of Health and Social Care
when_introduced_duration: Announced 22 June 2020. Changes come into effect on 6 July 2020 and 1 August 2020.
why_stated_aims: Advisory guidance to be eased for 2.2 million clinically extremely vulnerable people across England, as virus infection rates continue to fall
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
From 6 July 2020, those shielding from COVID-19 can gather in groups of up to 6 people outdoors and form a ‘support bubble’ with another household. The government shielding support package will remain in place until the end of July when people will no longer be advised to shield. 

From 1 August 2020, shielding people will no longer be advised to shield, but support will remain available from NHS volunteers and local councils. People will retain their priority for supermarket delivery slots, and still be able to access help with shopping, medication, phone calls and transport to medical appointments. While this group of clinically extremely vulnerable people should continue to follow strict social distancing measures, they will be able to participate in more activities such as visiting shops and places of worship.

From 1 August, those who need to work and cannot do so from home will be able to return to work as long as their workplace is COVID secure, adhering to the guidance available.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance published on meeting people from outside your household from 4 July, including that you can meet in a group of two households (including your support bubble), in any location – public or private, indoors or outdoors
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
when_introduced_duration: Published 23 June 2020. Guidance will apply from 4 July.
why_stated_aims: The government says it recognises how difficult it has been for people to be cut off from friends and family.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
Guidance on how to protect yourself and others when meeting people from other households from 4 July 2020. From 4 July you can meet in a group of two households in any location - public or private, or indoors or outdoors. It does not have to be the same household each time. It remains the case that people should socially distance from anyone not in your household of bubble.

From 4 July people should: only gather indoors in groups of no more than two households, even when dining out or going to the pub; only gather outdoors in groups of up to six people from different households or up to two households; only gather in larger groups of up to 30 for life events; not hold or attend celebrations when it is difficult to maintain social distancing; not stay overnight away from home with members of more than two households; limit the number of people you see; and limit social interactions with anyone outside the group you are attending a place with. Gatherings of more than 30 people will be banned. People can travel to meet people irrespective of distance but should continue to avoid using public transport wherever possible.

Key principles to follow to minimise risk of spreading infection: do not visit another household or allow others into your household if you have COVID-19 symptoms; check if guests have symptoms; follow strict social distancing guidelines with anyone outside your household or bubble; wash hands regularly; access private gardens externally where possible; avoid using toilets in other people’s home; clean surfaces regularly; avoid sharing plates and utensils; and avoid using paddling pools and garden equipment with people outside your household or bubble.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance on shielding and protecting people who are clinically extremely vulnerable is updated to reflect relaxing of shielding measures and to set out a series of steps for further relaxing shielding guidance which will come into effect on 6 July and 1 August
introduced_by: Public Health England
when_introduced_duration: Guidance initially published 21 March 2020 and last updated 23 June 2020. Changes come into effect on 6 July 2020 and 1 August 2020.
why_stated_aims: Due to COVID-19 infection rates having ‘decreased significantly’ the government has updated guidance for people who are shielding.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
From 6 July, the government will be advising: that shielded people may, if they wish, meet in a group of up to 6 people outdoors, including people from different households, while maintaining strict social distancing. They no longer need to observe social distancing with other members of their household. They may form a ‘support bubble’ with one other household. All those in the bubble can spend time together inside each other’s homes, including overnight, without socially distancing.
From 1 August the government will be advising that shielding will be paused. From this date those who were shielding should adopt strict social distancing rather than full shielding measures. In practice this means that from 1 August those who were shielding: can go to work (if they cannot work from home, and the business is COVID-safe); and can go outside to buy food, to places of worship and for exercise (whilst maintaining strict social distancing). Children who are clinically extremely vulnerable can return to their education settings if they are eligible. The advice is to still stay at home where possible and, if when going out, to follow strict social distancing.
