introduced_by: Ministry of Housing, Communities & Local Government
when_introduced_duration: Published 23 June 2020. Guidance will apply from 4 July.
why_stated_aims: The UK has ‘slowed the spread’ of COVID-19, and therefore, following earlier easements in May and June, further businesses and venues will be allowed to open on 4 July.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: All businesses and venues can reopen from 4 July, except for those listed below, which remain closed in law: Nightclubs; Casinos; Bowling alleys and Indoor skating rinks; Indoor play areas including soft-play; Spas; Nail bars, beauty salons and tanning salons; Massage, tattoo and piercing parlours; Indoor fitness and dance studios, and indoor gyms and sports venues/facilities; Swimming pools including water parks; and exhibition or conference centres must remain closed for events such as exhibitions or conferences. All other businesses and venues can reopen from 4 July. Guidance provides links to further guidance to ensure safe reopening. Businesses and venues should assist NHS Track and Trace by keeping a temporary record of customers and visitors for 21 days.

summary_of_measure_change: Prime Minister announces at the daily breifing that step 3 of the government’s ‘plan to recover’ will be implemented ‘as planned’ on 4 July in England. Relaxing of measures announced include moving from two metre rule to 'one metre plus', the opening of more sectors (eg hotels, places of worship, restaurants), and two households will be able to meet at a time, including staying over and indoors
introduced_by: Prime Minister
when_introduced_duration: Announced 23 June. Changes come into effect 4 July 2020.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Prime Minister speech key points: presents slides on the five tests for easing lockdown. Regarding the fifth test – that any adjustments to current measures do not risk a second peak – says he is thankful to the CMO and CSA for their advice and ‘can confirm the government judges we have met the fifth test and we are therefore satisfied that all five tests are still being met.’ Step 3 of the government’s ‘plan to recover’ will be implemented ‘as planned’ on 4 July in England. ‘After a long period of asking you, the British public, to follow very strict and complex rules to bring coronavirus under control, we can now make life easier for people to see more of their friends and family, and to help businesses get back on their feet and people back into jobs.’ (1) ‘Having considered all the evidence, while staying at two metres is preferable, we can now move to “one metre plus” where it is not possible for us to stay two metres apart.’ This means one metre apart plus mitigations (eg screens, handwashing facilities, being outdoors, face coverings on public transport). Setting out COVID-Secure guidance to help businesses take the right measures. (2) More sectors will be allowed to reopen on 4 July provided they are COVID-secure: hotels, B&Bs and self-contained holiday accommodation; caravan parks and campsites; places of worship and libraries; restaurants and cafes; bars, pubs and social clubs; cinemas and bingo halls; museums and galleries; hair salons and barbers; outdoor playgrounds and outdoor gyms. Outlines premises that must remain closed because of the risk of transmission (e.g. nightclubs, swimming pools and indoor gyms). Taskforces are being established for those sectors. (3) Two households will be able to meet at a time, including staying over, ‘indoors or outside, at your home, in a restaurant or pub, or in paid accommodation’, with social distancing. Groups of up to six can still meet outdoors. ‘As we give people back more control over their lives, we will be asking them to follow guidance on limiting their social contact, rather than forcing them to do so through legislation.’ The police can still break up ‘large and irresponsible’ gatherings. Repeats the stay alert messaging and continuing public health advice. Says the ‘fight is far from over’ and there will be local outbreaks. If it were ‘to begin to run out of control’, they would reverse some of these changes at a local or national level as required.

summary_of_measure_change: Findings from the review of two metre social distancing guidance is published, concluding that guidance should change to state that ‘2m or 1m with risk mitigation (where 2m is not viable) are acceptable’
introduced_by: Cabinet Office
why_stated_aims: The review was undertaken because there are severe economic costs to maintaining two metre distancing and it make it not financially viable for many businesses to operate. Industry bodies estimate that outlets could only make 30% of pre COVID-19 revenues with two metre distancing. 9.2m jobs have been furloughed, including over 1.75m jobs in sectors currently closed. Some of the jobs are at risk if reopening not viable at two metres. Similar countries have also recommended distances below two metres when prevalence has fallen.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
WhilE evidence shows that the relative risk may be two to ten times higher at one metre than two metres, mitigations can reduce the risk at one metre, so that it is broadly equivalent to being two metre apart. Guidance will change to state that ‘two metre or one metre with risk mitigation (where two metres is not viable) are acceptable’. Businesses should set out the mitigations they’ll introduce in their risk assessment. The COVID-secure risk assessment process already in place can be used to implement any change in guidance. SAGE has advised on 39 actions that can reduce risk of transmission, including: changing shift patterns so staff work in set teams; improving ventilation; changing room layouts to orientate people better; increase cleaning and handwashing; and encouraging use of protective screens and face coverings. Other mitigations include: limiting capacity; contactless purchases; one way systems; sending clear message to staff to stay home when symptomatic, or if a member of their household is symptomatic; and recording staff contact details and working patterns to support test and trace.

The review states that the social, economic, and health impacts of changing the two metres guidance are not evenly distributed, with people employed in closed sectors more likely to be young, not have a degree, and to work in low-skilled occupations.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance on 'working safely during coronavirus' is updated for people who work in the visitor economy including to reflect the change to the two metre rule and add guidance on support bubbles
introduced_by: Department for Digital, Culture, Media & Sport and VisitBritain
targeted_at: The visitor economy including people who work in hotels and guest accommodation, indoor and outdoor attractions, and business events and consumer shows
when_introduced_duration: The 'working safely during coronavirus' guidance was initially published 11 May 2020. Last updated 24 June 2020. The visitor economy section added on 23 June 2020.
why_stated_aims: The guidance is to help people within the visitor economy in England ‘understand how to work safely and protect their customers during the COVID-19 pandemic’.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
The guidance outlines ‘the processes and facilities that businesses must put in place before reopening on July 4 so that both staff and visitors can be kept safe’. It is relevant to the visitor economy, defined as encompassing ‘all staying and non-staying visitors and the activities and expenditure involved in supplying products and services for visitors by both the private and public sectors’. It includes: hotels and other guest accommodation; indoor and outdoor attractions; and business events and consumer shows. 
Considerations include: assessing the number of customers; limiting the number of customers; staggering the arrival of people; reviewing how customers will move through and around venue; managing queues; and encouraging use of handwashing and hand sanitiser. Measures include: introducing deep cleaning regimes; pre-booked and timed meal services; timed tickets for exhibitions, theme parks, galleries and attractions; one way systems, cashless payments; and social distancing to be in use for indoor and outdoor attractions.
At this time, venues should not permit live performances, including drama, comedy and music, to take place in front of a live audience. Staff should maintain social distancing in the workplace wherever possible. People who can work from home should continue to do so.

summary_of_measure_change: Guidance on 'working safely during coronavirus' is updated for people for people who work in close contact services including to reflect new guidance for keeping workers and clients safe
introduced_by: Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy and Department for Digital, Culture, Media & Sport
targeted_at: Close contact services including including hairdressers, barbers, beauticians, tattooists, sports and massage therapists, dress fitters, tailors and fashion designers
when_introduced_duration: The 'working safely during coronavirus' guidance was initially pusblished 11 May 2020. Last updated 24 June 2020. The close contact services section added 23 June 2020.
why_stated_aims: The guidance is to help people who provide close contact services, in England ‘understand how to work safely and protect their customers during the COVID-19 pandemic’.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
Guidance on how to open workplaces safely while minimising the risk of spreading COVID-19. It gives practical considerations of how this can be applied in the workplace. Close contact services include: hairdressers, barbers, beauticians, nail bars, tattooists, spray tanning studios, spas, sports and massage therapists, wellbeing and holistic locations, dress fitters, tailors and fashion designers.

Dress fitters, tailors and fashion designers were permitted to reopen on 15 June 2020. Hairdressers and barbershops will be permitted to reopen from 4 July 2020. The other services will remain closed until further notice, but this guidance can help to prepare for reopening.

Measures include: encouraging the use of hand washing and hand sanitiser; calculating maximum number of clients in line with social distancing guidelines; asking clients to attend alone where possible; inform clients and contractors of guidance prior to their arrival; reviewing how customers will move through and around premises; using outdoor spaces for queuing where possible; operate appointment-only system; review working practices to minimise the duration of contact with the client; limit use of changing facilities; ask clients COVID-19 screening questions ahead of their appointment; and staggering the arrival of people.

Staff should maintain social distancing in the workplace wherever possible. People who can work from home should continue to do so.

summary_of_measure_change:
Guidance on 'working safely during coronavirus' is updated for people who work in or run restaurants, pubs, bars, cafes or takeaways including to reflect guidance on support bubbles, social
distancing, test and trace and feedback from industry
introduced_by: Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy and Department for Digital, Culture, Media & Sport
targeted_at: Restaurants, pubs, bars and takeaway services
when_introduced_duration: Guidance initially published 11 May 2020. Last updated 24 June 2020.
why_stated_aims: The updated guidance is expanded from takeaways to venues providing service at the venue ahead of planned opening on 4 July 2020, to reflect guidance on support bubbles, social distancing, test and trace and feedback from industry.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
Guidance to help minimise the risk of transmission and protect the health of customers and visitors in restaurants, pubs, bars and takeaway venues. This guidance applies to any food preparation or service setting where food and drink is sold for consumption at venues or for takeaway or delivery. For example: restaurants, pubs, bars, beer gardens, food to go, cafes, social and similar clubs operating as bars and restaurants, and mobile catering and contact catering.

The guidance sets out a range of measures for pubs and restaurants to become COVID-19 secure, including: calculating the maximum number of customers that can reasonably follow social distancing guidelines at the venue; reconfiguring indoor and outdoor seating and tables to maintain social distancing guidelines; provide additional parking or facilities such as bike-racks, where possible, to help customers avoid using public transport; reviewing how customers will move through and around premises; encourage queuing outside where possible; managing the entry of customers, and the number of customers at a venue; requiring use of table service where possible; encouraging use of contactless ordering from tables where available; discouraging non-essential trips by staff within venues; encouraging customers to use hand sanitiser or handwashing facilities; and providing clear guidance on social distancing and hygiene as people arrive. 

At this time, venues should not permit live performances, including drama, comedy and music, to take place in front of a live audience. People who can work from home should continue to do so. Staff should maintain social distancing in the workplace wherever possible.

summary_of_measure_change: 10,000 residents and staff across over 100 care homes will be given COVID-19 tests as part of a new surveillance study to understand more about its spread in these settings
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
why_stated_aims: The research will give a detailed picture of COVID-19 infection in care homes in England. The aim is provide reassurance to those living and working in care homes and allow them to react quickly to outbreaks. Minister for Care Helen Whately says ‘Not only will this study provide important reassurance to thousands of residents and staff, it will also build our understanding of the rate of infection in care homes and add to our knowledge about the risk factors that mean the virus can affect individuals differently’.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms: Approximately 10,000 people in care homes will be given repeat testing as part of a new government study into COVID-19 to understand more about its spread in these settings (part of pillar 4 of the government's testing strategy). The study will take place across 106 care homes from the Four Seasons Health Care Group in England using swab tests and antibody tests for all consenting staff and residents over the next 12 to18 months. First results are expected in July. Findings will help inform future government strategy on the ongoing response to the virus.

summary_of_measure_change: Health Secretary calls on country to get tested as access to COVID-19 testing is expanded even further with six new 'walk through' local testing sites in England
introduced_by: Department of Health and Social Care
why_stated_aims: ‘Free and accessible testing is a cornerstone of the new NHS Test and Trace service’ and these new walk-through sites will bring testing into the ‘heart of communities’ and provide people will a convenient testing option close to where they live and work.
how_key_components_and_mechanisms:
Access to COVID-19 testing has increased further with six new ‘walk through’ local testing sites in England offering appointments to people without cars. This is in addition to the 68 drive through test sites across the country. The ‘walk-through’ sites will be expanded when there is demand from local communities. Home testing kits can also now be returned without booking a courier service. Also, 30 additional mobile testing units are now travelling the UK, which brings the total of mobile units to 147. This will increase to 236 by the end of July. Specialised translation services will soon be offered across a range of 68 drive-through testing sites. UK testing capacity has been expanded to more than 200,000 tests a day. Local authorities in England will now have greater autonomy to deliver different testing models suited to the needs of their local communities.
Health and Social Care Secretary Matt Hancock says ‘It has never been easier to get a free COVID-19 test, and our new walk-in centres are yet another way to get one. If you have symptoms, however mild, please get tested now to help stop the spread of the virus and protect the people around you’.

Milestone: National Framework published for local authorities and local decison-makers setting how to prevent, contain and manage COVID-19 local outbreaks
Detail:
Framework sets out how national and local partners, such as the NHS Test and Trace, the Joint Biosecurity Centre (JBC), local authorities, and Public Health England (PHE), will work with the public to prevent, contain and manage local COVID-19 outbreaks. Also outlines new regulations from 18 July that give local and national government additional powers to stop local transmission of the virus. Ministers are accountable nationally for setting this framework and Directors of Public Health are accountable for controlling local outbreaks. The guidance sets out six key principles for the effective implementation of an ‘integrated national and local system’: (1) primary responsibility is to make the public safe; (2) build on public health expertise and use a systems approach; (3) be open with data and insight; (4) build consensus between decision-makers; (5) follow well-established emergency management principles; and (6) consider equality, economic, social and health-related impacts of decisions.

Local outbreak plans are centred on 7 themes: healthcare and education settings; high-risk workplaces, communities and locations; local testing; contact tracing in complex settings; data integration; vulnerable people and diverse communities; and local boards and communications.

Where possible, actions to address local outbreaks will be undertaken in partnership with local communities. Local authorities will have the powers to close individual premises, public outdoor places and prevent specific events from the 18th July. Ministers have similar powers to take action against specific premises, places and events, as well as a power to ask local authorities to consider whether any actions have been unnecessary and should be revoked. To address more serious and wider-spread cases, ministers can use their existing powers (under the Public Health (Control of Disease) Act 1984) to implement more substantial restrictions. 

The framework sets out the local governance arrangements for COVID-19 outbreak plans. A table in the framework summarises the key roles for managing outbreaks within an individual setting, within a local authority area, and for those which cross regional boundaries. Local authorities deemed as areas for ‘enhanced support will be provided with increased national support, capacity and oversight, including additional resources deployed to augment the local teams’.

Milestone: Guidance published for local authorities on the new Health Protection Regulations that come into force on 18 July 2020

Regulations include powers for local authorities to: (1) restrict access to, or close, individual premises; (2) prohibit certain events (or types of event) from taking place; and (3) restrict access to, or close, public outdoor places (or types of outdoor public places). To make a direction under these regulations a local authority must gather evidence that meets the following 3 conditions: it must be in response to a serious and imminent threat to public health; it must be necessary to prevent, protect against, control or respond to the incidence or spread of COVID-19; and it must be a proportionate means of achieving that purpose to prevent. Local authorities should consult the police prior to issuing a direction if it 'prohibits, requires or restricts access to a premise, event or public outdoor place that is situated against a Local Resilience Forum boundary’. The Secretary of State can direct a local authority to issue or revoke a direction. Any direction issued by a local authority must be reviewed every seven days.

Detail: NHS Test and Trace and Public Health England will extend its partnership with local authorities 'to reach more people testing positive and their contacts' to stop the spread of COVID-19. Local areas will have ‘dedicated ring-fenced teams’ of contact tracers from the national NHS Test and Trace service. They will work on specific areas alongside local public health officials to provide a ‘more tailored service’. When the national team cannot make contact with someone within a set period of time, local public health officials can use data provided by NHS Test and Trace to follow up. The model, which integrates local knowledge with additional resources and data from the national service, has already been used in some local areas (Blackburn with Darwen, Luton and Leicester) and is now being offered to all upper tier local authorities. Builds on the recently published Contain Framework, which set out how national and local partners will work together to prevent, contain and manage outbreaks.

Milestone: New guidance published for supported living settings
Detail:
Department of Health and Social Care and Public Health England publish new guidance for managers, care and support workers and other staff in supported living settings to 'update and build on previous advice for these settings withdrawn on 13 May 2020'. The guidance sets out measures to maintain service delivery and manage outbreaks, and advice on visitors and testing, and signposts providers to existing guidance on areas including risk assessments, supporting staff, infection prevention control and PPE. It states that ‘given the different types of supported living and the associated care, support and help for people living there, this guidance cannot be specific to individual locations’ so local managers should use it to inform the development of their own ‘specific ways of working’.
The guidance states that to maintain service delivery, supported living providers should: ensure that lists of people in supported living are up to date; develop business continuity plans to help them manage emergency situations; update risk management plans for people who may find changes in routine challenging; work with local authorities to facilitate mutual aid, care and support plans; identify people who use direct payments or fund their own support; avoid sharing staff between settings; identify people who are clinically extremely vulnerable; and maintain oversight for people who are self-isolating. 
To reduce the risk of COVID-19 spreading across supported living facilities, measures should be followed, including social distancing, hygiene principles, self-isolation, use of PPE and cleaning. Staff should consider how the person they are supporting is most likely to understand the information and use the appropriate communication techniques. As lockdown measures continue to ease, providers should refer to guidance on ‘staying alert and social distancing’, which describes current options for meeting family members, friends and support bubbles. If there is any local tightening of lockdown measures, supported living settings in these locations are required to follow local guidelines. If a supported living worker has COVID-19 symptoms, they should refer to the guidance for ‘working safely during coronavirus’. If a worker comes into close contact with someone confirmed or suspected of having COVID-19 while not wearing PPE, they should inform their line manager and refer to the guidance for the ‘management of exposed healthcare workers’. If a person in supported living develops a COVID-19 infection, plans should be developed to ensure that person is supported to have their health checked in case further interventions are needed. The Health Protection Teams at Public Health England have an essential role in responding any COVID-19 outbreaks in supported living settings. Any people living in supported living or staff can access a COVID-19 test. Any individual being discharged from hospital into a supported living setting should be supported as if they were ‘possibly COVID-19 positive’.

Milestone: New Test and Trace app begins trial phase
Detail: New Test and Trace app begins the initial trial phase. The app aims to minimise the spread of COVID-19 alongside national and local contact tracing. It will ‘help people to understand if they are at risk of infection so they can take action to protect themselves and their communities’. The new app includes: alerts based on postcode, a QR check-in at venues, a symptom checker and test booking. The app will log the time and distance a user has spent near anyone, so it can alert them if any person they were near later tests positive for COVID-19. The app uses 'the latest in security technology' to protect user privacy, ‘so it tracks the virus, not people’. Residents from the Isle of Wight, Newham and NHS Volunteer Responders across England will take part in the trial.

Milestone: Government announces stronger enforcement measures as easements resume, with a number of culture, sport, leisure and business establishments permitted to reopen from 15 August
Detail:
The government announces a series of ‘tough’ new enforcement measures targeting the most ‘serious’ breaches of social distancing measures. Fines for people who repeatedly fail to wear face coverings where mandated will double to a maximum of £3,200. On the spot fines will be introduced for people hosting or facilitating illegal gatherings of more than 30 people. The Prime Minister says ‘most people in this country are following the rules and doing their bit to control the virus, but we must remain focused and we cannot be complacent. That is why we are strengthening the enforcement powers available to use against those who repeatedly flout the rules’.
Comes alongside announcement that the plan set out in the ‘roadmap to recovery’ which was paused for two weeks will resume from 15 August in England (except in areas where local restrictions are in place). This includes reopning bowling alleys, skating rinks, casinos, indoor play and soft play centres. Beauty salons, tattoo studios, spas and barbers across England will be able to offer all close contact services and treatment. Wedding receptions in the form of a sit-down meal in a COVID-secure location for up to 30 guests will be allowed to resume. Indoor theatres, music and performance venues will able to reopen with socially distanced audiences. Sports and business events pilots will resume, with a view to reopening competition venues for sports fans, with social distancing, from 1 October. Nightclubs, dance halls, and discotheques, sexual entertainment venues and hostess bars, remain closed. The government also announce that all staff offering close contact services should now wear a face mask in addition to a clear visor that covers the face.

Milestone: Public Health England publishes updated infection prevention and control guidance to support NHS organisations to further safely restart NHS services
Detail: New infection, prevention and control guidance for 'new ways of working during the continued pandemic' while restoring services reflects the move into the 'Third Phase' of the NHS response to COVID-19. States that it applies to 'all health and care settings' but 'does NOT apply to adult social care settings in England'. Outlines the new risk-assessed care pathway scenarios and key measures such as PPE use, extended use of face masks and coverings, and social distancing for these pathways. Patients now to be managed in 3 COVID-19 pathways – high risk (have or are likely to have COVID-19), medium risk (symptom free but no test result) and low risk (symptom free, a negative test result and have self-isolated prior to admission). Organisations should separate and minimise contact between these patient pathways and staff. Provides examples of patient groups and services that fall within each pathway. To enable early recognition of COVID-19 cases, screening and triaging should be undertaken 'prior to arrival at a care area, or as soon as possible on arrival, and allocated to the appropriate pathway'.  There is 'no change' in IPC recommendations when managing patients on a high risk pathway. Patients on a low risk pathway require 'Standard Infection Prevention & Control Precautions' for surgery or procedures. The other main changes in the guidance compared to previous ‘COVID-19: Infection Prevention and Control Guidance’ are: local and national prevalence and incidence data will be used to guide returning services as advised by country specific/public health organisations; sessional use of single use PPE items now only applies to extended use of facemasks for healthcare workers; use of facemasks (for staff) or face coverings (for patients and visitors) is recommended, in addition to social distancing and hand hygiene for staff, patients and visitors in both clinical and non-clinical areas; and, physical distancing of 2 metres as standard practice in all health and care settings.

Milestone: Government publishes new guidance on the use of face coverings for schools and other education institutions
Detail: Government publishes new guidance on the use of face coverings for schools and other education institutions that teach people in year 7 and above across England. Applies from 1 September 2020. The guidance cites the World Health Organisation advice that ‘children aged 12 and over should wear a mask under the same conditions as adults, in particular when they cannot guarantee at least a 1-metre distance from others and there is widespread transmission in the area’. The guidance says the government is ‘not recommending face coverings are necessary in education settings generally because a system of control, applicable to all education environments, provides additional mitigating measures’. However, school and colleges have the 'discretion' to require face coverings in indoor communal areas where ‘social distancing cannot be safely managed’. Eg in areas where the layout makes it difficult to maintain social distancing when students and staff are moving around, when these extra measures may provide additional confidence to parents and support the full return of students to school or college. Guidance says that face coverings can ‘have a negative impact on learning and teaching and so their use in the classroom should be avoided’. Where local restrictions apply in areas where transmission of COVID-19 is high, face coverings should be worn by adults and pupils when moving around indoors where social distancing is difficult to maintain. No one should be excluded from education on the grounds that they are not wearing a face covering.

Milestone: Government announces a new £500m funding package that will be invested in COVID-19 test trials using latest technology and increased testing capacity
Detail: The government announces a new £500m funding package for next generation testing technology and increased testing capacity. This will include a new community wide trial that launches in Salford to assess the benefits of repeat population testing. The pilot will explore how regular repeat testing can be made as accessible as possible and will inform how to scale community testing across the country. Existing trials in Southampton and Hampshire, using a saliva test and a rapid 20-minute test, are also being expanded using the new funding. Trials will also look at the benefits of mass testing, and how the testing programme can be improved and scaled up ahead of winter. Successful trials will be expanded and rolled out more widely. Health and Social Care Secretary Matt Hancock says ‘we are backing innovative new tests that are fast, accurate and easier to use and will maximise the impact and scale of testing, helping us to get back to a more normal way of life’.

Milestone: The Transport Secretary announces the introduction of a more targeted approach to travel corridors by separating some islands from mainland countries
Detail: The Transport Secretary Grant Shapps says that as the Joint Biosecurity centre’s resources have ‘strengthened’ the government has been able to ‘collaborate much more closely with other governments and their health authorities’. This has led to a more ‘forensic picture’ of the situation in other countries. However, international data is still too ‘patchy’ to allow for the implementation of a regionalised system for international travel corridors. However, where regions have natural boundaries, like an island, Grant Shapps says that the ‘Passenger Locator forms combined with NHS Test and Trace will give us a clear picture of where infections are coming from’. Therefore a new islands policy has been introduced. The data and capacity exists to be able to remove or add specific islands from quarantine. However, the islands this will apply too must collect robust, reliable and internationally comparable data, must have direct flights to the UK (or transport must have taken place through quarantine exempt territories), and FCDO travel advice should align as far as practicable.

Milestone: Government announces that the NHS COVID-19 app will launch on 24 September in England and Wales – app includes QR check-in at venues
Detail:
The government announces the launch of the NHS COVID-19 app across England and Wales on 24 September. The app incudes a QR check-in at venues, so customers and visitors can check-in on entry to venues on their smartphones instead of filling out a check-in book or tool specific to the business. Businesses across England and Wales, including pubs, restaurants, hairdressers and cinemas, are being asked to ensure they have NHS QR code posters visible on entry so customers who have downloaded the new app can easily check-in. Universities, hospitals, leisure premises, civic centres and libraries are also being asked to display QR code posters in communal areas. The QR codes can be downloaded via a website to display as posters. Health and Social Care Secretary Matt Hancock says ‘QR codes provide an easy and simple way to collect contact details to support the NHS Test and Trace system’.

Businesses that already use their own QR system are being encouraged to switch to the NHS Test and Trace QR code. An alternative check-in method must be maintained to collect the contact details of those who don’t have the app. The press release states that ‘ongoing trials in Newham, on the Isle of Wight and with NHS Volunteer Responders show the app is highly effective when used alongside traditional contact tracing to identify contacts of those who have tested positive for coronavirus’.

Milestone: New social distancing measures come into place, including the 'rule of 6'
Detail: From 14 September, people cannot meet with other households socially in groups of more than 6. This applies indoors and outdoors, including private homes. Exceptions to this rule include COVID-19 secure venues, such as places of worship, restaurants and hospitality venues, can still host larger numbers in total but groups of up to 6 must not mix or form larger groups. Individual households or support bubbles that include more than 6 people can still meet. The rule also does not apply to education and work settings. Organised team sports, as well as weddings and funeral up to 30 people, can still proceed. Measures apply to England. From 18 September it will be mandatory for certain business to have a system to collect NHS Test and Trace data. COVID-19 guidance is also updated to reflect these changes. Guidance for support bubbles is also updated to state that 'From 14 September, if you form or continue in a support bubble, you cannot then change your support bubble. It does not have to be the same support bubble you may have been in previously.'

Milestone: Guidance published on COVID-19 antibody home test kit – initially, home tests only available to care home workers and shortly after changed to include all social care workers
Detail:
Free NHS antibody testing kits introduced for care workers. New guidance sets out instructions on how to carry out the test, post the sample and get the results. It states that results take 3 to 7 days. Emphasises that it is currently only available to care workers in England and Wales. Existing antibody testing guidance is also updated to state that 'stocks are limited and tests need to be prioritised'. To be eligible for a free home testing kit you must: live in England or Wales; be 18 or over; do any job in a care home; be unable to get to an NHS test site to take the test. It clarifies that 'Clinicians will always be able to request the tests for patients in both hospital and social care settings if they think it’s appropriate.' All NHS staff and social care staff also continue to be able to assess testing at NHS test sites.

The guidance was subsequently changed. On 17 September, the link to the antibody testing service was removed and the guidance set out that the Department of Health and Social Care is working directly with organisations in the adult social care sector in order to offer tests. On 24 September, at-home kits were made available again but eligibility changed to any adults paid to work in adult social care.

Milestone: Government announces new legal requirements for self-isolation and measures to support and enforce this
Detail: From 28 September, people will be legally required to self-isolate following a positive COVID-19 test result or being instructed by NHS Test and Trace to self-isolate due to contact with someone with a positive test result. To enforce self-isolation, this government will bring in new fines for those breaching the rules - starting at £1,000 and increasing to up to £10,000 for repeat offences or the ‘most egregious breaches, including for those preventing others from self-isolating’. NHS Test and Trace call handlers will make regular contact with people self-isolating and escalate suspicions of non-compliance to Local Authorities or police. Police resources will be used to check compliance in high incidence areas and risk groups - high-profile cases of non-compliance may be prosecuted. Government will introduce a payment of £500 for people on lower incomes who will lose income due to self-isolating. To be eligible, people must be: asked by NHS Test and Trace to self-isolate; unable to work from home so will lose income as a result of self-isolation; and claiming one or more of the following benefits - Universal Credit, Working Tax Credits, income-related Employment and Support Allowance, income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance, Income Support, Pension Credit or Housing Benefit. The support scheme should be in place by 12 October, but eligible people can receive payments backdated from 28 September. Related guidance on self-isolating is updated to reflect the change.

Milestone: Government publishes list of where COVID-19 tests are being prioritised
Detail: Goverment publishes a list of settings where tests are being prioritised, as 'demand has rapidly increased and is currently above these [capacity] levels'. Testing will be prioritised: first, for hospital patients; second, for staff, residents and new admissions in care homes; third, for NHS staff, including GPs and pharmacists; fourth, for targeted testing for outbreak management and surveillance studies; fifth, for symptomatic teaching staff; and then for the general public when they have symptoms, prioritising areas of high incidence. Announcing this publication of the list in the House of Commons, Matt Hancock states that: 'I want to reinforce this important point: the system relies on people coming forward for tests if—and only if—they have symptoms of coronavirus or have been specifically advised to by a health professional. The testing capacity we have is valuable and we must together prioritise it for the people who need it the most.'

Milestone: Childcare and unpaid care exempted from interhousehold mixing restrictions in local areas of intervention
Detail: In some areas with local restrictions, interhousehold mixing is banned. Matt Hancock announces that from 22 September, people can form 'care bubbles' to allow informal childcare and caring arrangements to continue despite such restrictions. The arrangement must work on a consistent basis with families sharing caring responsibilities with another household. A relative or a friend can care for a child under the age of 14 or a vulnerable adult from a different household. The exemption does not apply for one-off arrangements, such as play dates. It will apply in all current and future areas under current restrictions to ban household mixing. Registered childcare is already exempt.

Milestone: 10pm closing time for pubs, restaurants and other businesses comes in, along with other new restrictions
Detail: New social distancing restrictions come into place on 24 September (announced 22 September), supported by an initial £60m for additional enforcement activity by local authorities and police. The measures are expected to remain in place until March 2021. Guidance that face coverings and visors be worn in close contact services will become law. Hospitality and retail staff must wear face coverings. Customers in hospitality venues must wear face coverings, except when seated at a table to eat or drink - table service now required in licensed premises. People who are already exempt from the existing face covering obligations will continue to be so. Businesses selling food or drink, social clubs, casinos, bowling alleys, amusement arcades, funfairs, theme parks, adventure parks and activities, and bingo halls, must be closed between 10pm and 5am. Businesses must display official NHS QR code posters so customers can ‘check-in’ on the NHS test and app. Support groups are limited to 15 people. Indoor organised sport for over 18s is no longer exempt from the rule of 6 (except for disabled people). Other changes in advice announced include that office workers who can work effectively from home should do so. The planned reopening of business conferences, exhibition halls and large sporting events will not happen from 1 October.

Milestone: NHS Test and Trace launches the NHS COVID-19 App to help identify contacts of people who test positive for COVID-19
Detail: The NHS COVID-19 app launches 'to help control COVID-19 transmission alongside national and local contact tracing', following 'positive trials and rigorous testing'. It is part of the NHS Test and Trace programme and will help identify contacts of people who test positive for COVID-19. The app is for anyone aged 16 and over, and is available in multiple languages. Major mobile network operators have confirmed that in-app activity will not come out of customers’ data allowance. The app's contact tracing feature uses Bluetooth to log the amount of time a person spends near other app users, and the distance between them, so it can alert a person if they have been close to someone who later tests positive for COVID-19. The app will advise people to self-isolate if they have been in close contact with a confirmed case. People can use the app to check symptoms, book a free test if needed, get test results, and check the level of COVID-19 risk in their postcode district. The app has a QR check-in for people to use to check-in at venues - it will alerts someone if they have recently visited somewhere they may have come into contact with someone who later tests positive for COVID-19. Businesses legally have to display NHS Test and Trace QR codes for customers. The aim is that the app  'tracks the virus, not people' and uses data security technology to protect privacy. The app does not hold personal information such as names, addresses or dates of birth, and only requires the first half of anyone’s postcode to ensure local outbreaks can be managed. No personal data is shared with the government or the NHS.

Milestone: New restrictions come in: legal duty to self-isolate, fines of £10,000 for businesses subject to COVID-19 Secure requirements in law, increased restrictions on weddings and civil partnership ceremonies
Detail: Legal duty to self-isolate comes in (announced 20 September - separate entry) and increased restrictions on gatherings. People are legally required to self-isolate following a positive COVID-19 test result or being instructed by NHS Test and Trace to self-isolate due to contact with someone with a positive test result. Also from 28 September, a wider range of leisure and entertainment venues, services provided in community centres, and close contact services are subject to COVID-19 Secure requirements in law and fines of up to £10,000 for repeated breaches. Employers must not require or encourage staff required to self-isolate to come to work. Businesses must remind people to wear mandated face coverings. Other measures that come into force include: £500 for people on lower incomes who will lose income due to self-isolating; NHS Test and Trace call handlers increasing contact with those self-isolating; police resources used to check compliance in highest incidence areas and in high-risk groups. Weddings, civil partnership ceremonies, receptions are restricted to 15 people (down from 30). Other significant standalone life events (except funerals) are subject to the ‘rule of six’.

Milestone: Government publishes a Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) Strategy setting out 'how government is preparing for a second wave of COVID-19'
Detail: The government publishes a new PPE strategy for England to 'stabilise and build resilience' from September 2020 to March 2021. Following an 'emergency response' approach to PPE during the early period of the COVID-19 pandemic, the strategy sets out 'how government is preparing for a second wave of COVID-19'. To respond to future demand increases, the Department of Health and Social Care is building a 'strategic stockpile’ equivalent to around 4 months’ stock of each product category. Government is also reviewing stockpile requirements for future pandemics (not just COVID-19). Due to the ‘significant differences in the nature of the market for each category’ of medical-grade PPE, the Department of Health and Social Care is taking a category-by-category approach within the PPE strategy. A ‘robust plan’ has been developed to stand procurement and distribution back up at pace to provide an effective and timely response to any future need. Government is reviewing future COVID-19 PPE requirements to maintain the increased level of UK PPE manufacture, and anticipates that UK-based supply will meet 70% of forecasted demand in England in December for all types of PPE (less than 1% of PPE was manufactured in the UK pre COVID-19). Aiming to shift towards more sustainable and innovative PPE, PPE will be reusable by design going forward, where possible. The Department of Health and Social Care says it is ‘listening to the reported practical difficulties with the use of some PPE experienced by women and Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic (BAME) individuals’ and is taking action to ensure ‘user needs are adequately addressed in future provisions of PPE’.
